BOSTON UNIVERSITY
School of Public Relations and Communications
84 Exeter Street • Boston 16 Massachusetts
April 6, 1956
As an honorary member of the Metropolitan School Study Council,
and more particularly as a professional educator, you are undoubtedly
attempting to keep fully informed on the progress that is being
made in the field of educational television, in both areas of on-
the-air programs and closed-circuit teaching techniques. For this
reason, we believe you may well be interested in the activities of
the national professional association which is concerned with
these matters.
The Association for Education by Radio-Television, founded 17
years ago, is a non-profit educational organization incorporated
under the lavra of the State of Illinois and dedicated to both the
utilization and evaluation of educational radio and television
materials, both in the commercial and non-commercial industries.
As stated in its constitution, the broad purpose of the Association
is to "extend and improve the educational use of radio and TV,"
AERT membership is nation-wide and includes teachers and ad¬
ministrators on all levels of education, commercial broadcasters,
religious broadcasters, civic leaders, parents, and representatives
of many leading community groups.
The advantages of membership in AERT are many. They include
the following:
AERT publishes its monthly Journal during the academic year.
The Journal contains stimulating articles on a diverse number of
topics including areas of communication theory, practical program
and promotional ideas, helpful how-to-do-it and how-to-find-it
suggestions, as well as reports on listenerTs councils and similar
evaluational activities.
AERT serves as one of the sponsors of the National Tape Re¬
cording Catalog and Re-recording Service, a project set up in co¬
operation with the Department of Audio-Visual Instruction of the
